page.title: 06DANGER ON RIVER AVON
page.content: 4th July 1985 It has been the wettest June for 35 years so the River Avon was at a very high level and was flowing fast. A fourteen year old boy was drowned by the weir at Evesham. He was one of three boys in a two man canoe. None of the boys had a lifejacket on at the time. The current swept them downstream and the canoe overturned. One of the boys tried to save his friend, but the boy was washed away. Police searched the river but there was no trace of the boy. It was not until ten days later that his body was found near the ferry at Hampton. Now police are advising everyone to wear a lifejacket and never go out on the river alone. Everyone who liked fishing, swimming, diving, boating and canoeing should join a club and have some training.
